Suppose V is a subvector space of \RNr[n] with \dim(V)=20 , and let S be a subset of \RNr[n] . How many vectors can there be in S if
S contains at least 20 vectors, possibly infinitely many.
It is possible to select from S a basis for V , and this basis must have exactly 20 vectors.
\span(S) contains V
S contains at least 20 vectors, possibly infinitely many.
It is possible to select from S a basis for \span(S) , and \span(S) has dimension at least 20 as it contains V . Therefore S must have at least \dim(\span(S)) \geq 20 vectors.
V contains \span(S) .
S can have any number of vectors.
All we know is that \span(S) is contained in V . But this relationship does not impose any constraint on the number of vectors in S .
S is linearly independent and V contains S .
S can have at most 20 vectors.
S can be completed to a basis of V . Such a basis has exactly 20 vectors. Therefore S can have at most 20 vectors.
For each of the statements below decide if it is true or false.
If \EuScript{B} = (\Vect{a}, \Vect{b}, \Vect{c} ) is an ordered basis for a vector space V , then \Vect{x}_{\EuScript{B}} = (2,-3,7) means that
True!
If \EuScript{B} = (\Vect{a}, \Vect{b}, \Vect{c} ) is an ordered basis for a vector space V , then \Vect{x}_{\EuScript{B}} = (2,-3,7) means that \Vect{x} is a vector in \RNr[3] .
False!
The fact that the coordinate vector \Vect{x}_{\EuScript{B}} of \Vect{x} has three coordinates means that \Dim{V}=3 . However, V need not be contained in \RNr[3] . The statement in question is false.

If \EuScript{B} = (\Vect{a}, \Vect{b}, \Vect{c} ) is an ordered basis for a vector space V , then \Vect{x}_{\EuScript{B}} = (2,-3,7) means that \Vect{x} can be turned into a vector in \RNr[3] by converting to standard coordinates.
False!

An arbitrary vector space V need not have anything like standard coordinates. Even if V has some set of standard coordinates, changing from \EuScript{B} -coordinates to standard coordinates does not change the vector in V to a vector in \RNr[3] (unless, of course, V=\RNr[3] in which case \Vect{x} has been in \RNr[3] all along).
